The '''Southern Fiefs''' or '''Outlands''' of [[Gondor]] were the seabord lands south of [[Anórien]],<ref>{{HM|N}}, entry ''Sunlending'', p. 776</ref> the fiefs of Gondor outside the [[Pelennor]].<ref>{{HM|UI}}, entry ''Outlands'', p. 523</ref>

These seaboard lands along the [[Bay of Belfalas]] provided much of [[Minas Tirith]]'s needs: [[fish]] from the [[Ethir Anduin|Ethir]], [[:Category:Flowers|flowers]] from [[Lossarnach]], and at earlier times, stone from [[Anórien]]. The fiefs also provided skilled soldiers.
 
==History==
After the [[Great Plague]] the [[Corsairs of Umbar]] raided the Gondorian coasts up to [[Anfalas]], until [[Umbardacil]] avenged retook [[Umbar]] in {{TA|1810}}.<ref>{{App|Gondor}}</ref>

Years later the Corsairs once more harried the coasts of Gondor during the time of [[Cirion]].<ref name=Stewards>{{App|Stewards}}</ref> 

In {{TA|2758}}, when Gondor and [[Rohan]] were plagued by the [[Long Winter]], three great fleets sailed from Umbar and [[Harad]] and raided and landed on the Gondorian coasts, as north as the mouth of [[Isen]]. Travelling up [[Lefnui]] and Isen they even attacked [[Rohan]]. Before the spring of {{TA|2759|n}}, [[Beregond (Steward of Gondor)|Beregond]] overcame the invaders.<ref name=Stewards/><ref>{{App|Eorl}}</ref> 

By the late [[Third Age]], most regions of Gondor were either deserted or overrun and only the Southern Fiefs remained. During the [[War of the Ring]], the Outlands are under attack from the south by a large army of [[Corsairs of Umbar|Corsairs from Umbar]], allies of [[Mordor]], and they sent small reinforcements to [[Minas Tirith]].<ref>{{RK|V1}}</ref>

==Known fiefs==
The Southern Fiefs were:
* [[Dor-en-Ernil]]
* [[Lossarnach]]
* [[Lebennin]]
* [[Belfalas]]
* [[Ethir Anduin]]
* [[Lamedon]]
* [[Anfalas]] and the [[Pinnath Gelin|Green Hills]]
* [[Blackroot Vale]]
* [[Ringló Vale]]

==Etymology==
A [[wikipedia:Fiefdom|fief]] is, in feudalism, a piece of inheritable land given to a vassal. The vassal returned this gift with (military) allegiance and/or revenue.
